Dear Ms. Waidelich:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
March 9, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Three of seventeen new hire employee files reviewed lacked an evaluation completed
by the facility within 90 days (per agency policy). The three evaluations were written by
the supervisor but had not yet been reviewed with the staff member over thirty days post
competition. One of the six annual evaluations was not completed for the employees
who have been working at the facility for over a year.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2021 Interim, CAP approval date 05/14/2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
- Staff evaluations should be completed in a timely manner. The facility was
able to provide this consultant with the written evaluation from the supervisor,
but it was noted that it has not been reviewed with the staff member. These
evaluations were still pending review after 30 days of completion. It was
discussed about scheduling the evaluations timely and bringing the computer
to the evaluation for the worker to sign off on report during the review
meeting.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility had nine special investigations during this period under review with six
resulting in corrective action plans. The non-compliances included behavior
management, restraint techniques, staff qualifications, and sufficiency of staff. The
facility’s corrective action plan compliance is monitored quarterly and have completed all
current corrective action plans.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
Chief Administrator noted over this reporting period COVID-19 has continued to have
an impact on the facility, primarily regarding staff turnover and recruitment. There has
also been a number of quarantines due to COVID-19 which has left the facility short
staffed with supervisors having to spend most of their time on the floor with limited
time to complete office duties. The facility continues to offer sign on bouses and
referral bonuses for current staff referring candidates. Program Manager leadership
changed a year ago and proper documentation and follow through has been a main
focus of the current Program Manager. The facility has shown improvement in
multiple documentation areas based on management/ leadership follow up and
holding staff accountable. Chief Administrator reports through the corrective action
plans the facility has seen a positive impact on the facility. They have seen positive
outcomes with the updated Onboarding Checklist with additional Project Coordinator
audit which has improved the onboarding process and Employee Records
compliance. Additionally, implementation of Director review of random Updated
Service Plans and leadership weekly walk throughs of the budling for maintenance
and cleanliness checks has improved compliance consistency.
Interviews:
Staff and youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or
concerns were raised. Some of the youth at the facility are nonverbal youth and this
consultant was able to view and interact with these youth. The youth appeared to be
in positive spirits by laughing and clapping their hands. Staff were viewed meeting the
needs of the children and interacting with them on a one-to-one basis. The staff all
reported feeling supported by direct supervisors as well as administration.
5

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
